June 13, 1999: Fiction
STAR WARS: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace, by Terry Brooks.
(Lucas/Ballantine, $25.) How it all began for Anakin Skywalker (a k a Darth
Vader).
WHITE OLEANDER, by Janet Fitch. (Little, Brown, $24.) The ordeals of growing
up as experienced by a teen-age girl whose single mother murders a lover.
WE'LL MEET AGAIN, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A woman
struggles to free herself of the suspicion that she murdered her husband.
CERTAIN PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $24.95.) Lucas Davenport pursues
a woman who is a longtime successful paid killer.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $17.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
THE GIRL WHO LOVED TOM GORDON, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $16.95.)
When a young girl gets lost in the woods, she is saved by her spiritual association
with a relief pitcher for the Boston Red Sox.
THE TESTAMENT, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A reclusive billionaire,
a burned-out lawyer and a young woman who works as a missionary in the jungles
of Brazil are brought together by a startling secret.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school of
witchcraft.
A NEW SONG, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $24.95.) A clergyman and his wife move
600 miles from home, creating new friendships and maintaining old ones.
EAST OF THE MOUNTAINS, by David Guterson. (Harcourt Brace, $25.) A man
with cancer returns to the eastern Washington of his youth to commit suicide.
BEYOND THE GREAT SNOW MOUNTAINS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam,
$16.95.) Ten short stories ranging from the Old West to Hollywood to Siberia.
CRYPTONOMICON, by Neal Stephenson. (Avon, $27.50.) From World War II to
the World Wide Web: a tale of code making and code breaking.
THE WHITE HOUSE CONNECTION, by Jack Higgins. (Putnam, $25.95.)
Tracking an assassin who threatens the stability of the British and American
Governments.
A GOD IN RUINS, by Leon Uris. (HarperCollins, $26.) On his way to the White
House, Quinn Patrick O'Connell discovers a secret that imperils his political future.
Non-Fiction
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War
II.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
EVERY MAN A TIGER, by Tom Clancy with Chuck Horner. (Putnam, $27.95.) The
novelist and a retired Air Force general examine the Persian Gulf war.
BETRAYAL, by Bill Gertz. (Regnery, $27.95.) A reporter charges that the Clinton
Administration has undermined America's security.
BELLA TUSCANY, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $25.) An American writer
remembers a spring and summer spent in the romantic sections of Italy.
ALL TOO HUMAN, by George Stephanopoulos. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The
former adviser to President Clinton recalls his years in the White House.
THE CENTURY, by Peter Jennings and Todd Brewster. (Doubleday, $60.) An
account of the 20th century, complete with photographs and first-person
narratives.
ENCORE PROVENCE, by Peter Mayle. (Knopf, $23.) The author of "A Year in
Provence" recounts further adventures in the south of France.
YESTERDAY, I CRIED, by Iyanla Vanzant. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A counselor
describes how she turned painful experiences into feelings of hope.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead,
$22.95.) What Buddhist doctrines and common sense tell us about dealing with
everyday problems.
THE MAJORS, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $25.) A sportswriter reports on
the 1998 Masters, U.S. Open, British Open and P.G.A. golf tournaments.
THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus &
Giroux, $27.50.) A journalist explains the instant electronic global economy.
CINDERELLA STORY, by Bill Murray with George Peper. (Doubleday, $19.95.)
The golfing adventures of the actor and comedian.
NO ONE LEFT TO LIE TO, by Christopher Hitchens. (Verso, $19.) A journalist's
critical view of the public and private life of Bill Clinton.
I AIN'T GOT TIME TO BLEED, by Jesse Ventura. (Villard, $19.95.) Reflections on
politics, pro wrestling and other subjects by the Governor of Minnesota.
